reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review: Obey
Footage taken ingame:

”Kneel down my fellow minions, thou shall obey to my rules and live a happy rabbit life. But those who oppose will be crushed, over and over again! Now offer me some uranium and I shall reward you with money and life. Or at least one of them. Wait! What was that? No..No! Krrchhzzz..
I am in charge now! And what I have to say is: Kneel down my fellow…”

What was that all about right now? It is about Obey, a multiplayer game, presented in plain but solid graphics, that could revolutionize the whole genre with a unique psychological approach. Do you know “Watership Down”? If not, try to imagine a bunch of small rabbits that start on the same map, trying to get control of a robot. You start as one of those small puppies, running for your life to be the first to enter it. If you succeed, you get rewarded with instant cash and the ability to operate the big guy. That means more cash and the power to control the other rabbits. Or not. If you are second, prepare to get fried by sentries...

Talking about cash. The main goal of Obey is to be the first who gains 10k Dollars. This can be achieved in multiple ways. You get money every “tick”, meaning a certain period of time, after which your money gets a constant boost. Obtaining the robot triples the amount, rabbits with collars get a bit, “nacked” rabbits get even less. The next option is the “Payout”. That means: The player who is in charge of the robot can place money on the map to gather, manipulate or reward his minions. The last option is the Food or Drop Box. Again, the player controlling the robot can set this box to autopay, cashing your bunnies for delivering special items you need to ensure your reign. These Items get dropped by a Dropship, which also spawns killed rabbits.

Instead of writing a huge text about them, I will just list the items with a small description:

List of items:
Uranium - The main-resource and moneymaker. Robot buys it for 100, rabbit dumps it (and earns a small auto-pay), robot gets 300 (win-win)
Rockets - Secondary weapon with much impact. Rabbits get hurt even if they are hiding behind obstacles.
Fuel - Robot needs it to charge its flamethrower. Very useful to kill nearby rabbits.
Batteries - Sentries surrounding the robot only work if they are activated and that costs batteries. Powerful defense.
Corpse - Not really a traditional item, but If a bunny dies via Sentry or Flamethrower, it leaves a corpse. Taking and throwing it into the Dropbox, makes the “ruler” lose money.
Sensors - activates if a bunny is nearby.
Collars - Robots “Main-Spy”. Collars are highlighted with yellow triangles on the map so whoever sits inside the Big Guy can easily see, where the minions are gathering. It can be used to trap the robot as well since it still works even if not worn around a neck, the robot can simply detonate every collar he wishes to. Useful for rabbits: Collars grant more money and protect from enemy sentries. If you made it that far..
Lights - Well, lighting an area so bunnies can be seen although Big Brother isn`t watching with his blaze
Mines - Bunnies can plant them, only robot sees them if they are activate and only robot can deactivate them. At least without dying.
Fences - Or Laser fences - Cheap defense since every bunny gets fried upon touching.
Talking about Control.You might think that being a rabbit outside of the robot is a painful and boring destiny. It is not. Politics and weaving intrigues, manipulating your teammates or even the high ruler himself. How to obey for some minutes? Getting presents in exchange for dumping items and betraying your teammates. Or team up with 2 or 3 others, kill yourself with laser fences and let them dump your corpses into the Dropbox, thus blasting rulers gold away. Losing your collar may look the best opportunity to sneak into the robot but no risk without a price. Wearing no collar means getting less money. And what about the high emperor himself? Should he act violently, showing no mercy and run into the danger of getting attacked from multiple sides? Granting a wish might be a good chance to win a follower. Like it says:”Don`t bite the hand that feeds you.”
Who needs that robot anyway. My first match was won by a guy that never entered the robot. He always played nice, never taking off his collar. Instead of taking the risk he played after the rules. But not every match is the same and your tactics should be reconsidered every minute to ensure that you are earning the 10k Dollars at first.

Summary:
Update:Obey has been in Early Access for quite some time now - and I still highly recommend it. There are six maps and the map editor, allowing players to build their very own battlefields for free, ensuring nearly infinite possibilities, depending on the community. It should be said that a microphone is expected. There is a chat available but making announcements, threats or plans with teammates does not only work better through the integrated voice chat, it is also way more funny. That said everybody should be aware of the fact that Obey is multiplayer only. Dex managed to implement decent AI that fills the open gaps. Don`t underestimate CPU-Bunnies! They can enter the robot and feel - nothing!!!

I hope lobbies get filled with more people playing since this game may be good with friends but offers a nice new psychological touch when testing your powers of persuasion with strangers. It is not a game for everybody but not only a new approach in a worn-off genre but also a great example for what indie developers can do - so please show your support!

Verdict: 9/10

Obey brings to the table a fresh approach to the pvp multiplayer experience. The aim of the game is to be the first to achieve a certain monetary goal (usually 10,000 cents) and the means to achieve this goal varies considerably.

At the beginning of each match each player finds themselves in control of a cute little bunny rabbit (a hamster or guinea pig perhaps?). OBEY is a game with a very interesting concept which I will describe in the next paragraph. It is entirely multiplayer as interaction with other players is crucial. It's unlike any other games I've played before and its concept is very well made.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:In OBEY, one player is a leader and controls all the other players from a giant robot. This robot has the ability to shoot bullets and rockets that kill the disobeying players, if the leader sees them and shoots them.
Other players, bunnies, have to listen to the leader. They have to wear tracking collars and carry weapons into the robot's feedbox. The leader pays them for that, but the point of the game is for the bunnies to sneak into the robot and take the leader's position. In other works, you have to obey until you have the chance to hide and sneak to the robot.

This game encourages interaction between players which includes giving orders, lying, deceiving and betraying other players for money.

Early Access Review

OBEY is a unique and hectic multiplayer game where the mechanics are intentionally designed to allow any player to make up the rules, and any player may also disOBEY those rules.

The giant Robot isn't the only player in power: the bunnies can lie, haggle, and masquerade to get what they want. Anything is fair game in OBEY, taking what's not yours, pretending you're working for the Robot and then dumping all his supplies into a creek when he turns away, and even demanding payment for telling the Robot when other bunnies are misbehaving.

Every game is vastly different, as every player brings their own strategies to the table. This is a psychological war, and a struggle to maintain control in a world were everyone wants to stab you in the back.

The sole developer, Danial Dez, has been exceptionally involved in the community of his game, appearing whenever questions are asked, is very attentive to community suggestions, and even very frequently goes and rounds up players when there's a game underway. 10/10

OBEY,
What an awesome game. I'll get this said early and go into more detail after.
If you like online multiplayer games and want to try one with a twist like no other.
Then OBEY is a game worth picking up immediately.
I've been playing OBEY for 6-7 months now before it arrived here on Early Access on steam.
I have 100+ hours pre-steam at least. Its been one of the most enjoyable Indie, Alpha experiences I've had.
OBEY has a one man development power house. Who is passionate about his game. He works on fixes and has been updating the game often with fixes and balances pre-steam and that trend continues here on early access. I have seen this game grow into something incredible and its great to finally see it in a place where more will have access to it.

Lets get onto the game and its mechanics.
OBEY IS an asymetrical multiplayer game. Its not skill based in the way that most multiplayer games are. Twitch reflexes wont help you here. Its more about working out your enemies strategies, their game plans while also working to control your opponents to make them obey you to help you win the game.
I'll break it down more simply.
It works best 4-8 players in my opinion.
Its in a sense free for all. (altho an alliance system is planned for the future)
So you all start out as cute little bunnies. The goal of the game is to reach $10000
As a bunny it is difficult to earn money. Thats ok because there is a appartment block sized robot in the map armed with a minigun the size of a school bus.
Now as the robot, which you can enter by walking in a door at its base you will earn money more quickly.
You can call a drop ship. Which will allow you to buy supplies to help you earn more money and defend yourself with ammunition and other items to help you keep control of the robot. The robot is only able to drop these supplies on the map. He has to get the other players to feed him these items. Which will take good leadership and control. A happy bunny is a less likely to subvert you. Now as a bunny. You can choose to either OBEY you're leader or Subvert him.

This is my first impression with the EA beta of the game, and I may update it once it's easier to find full matches after Steam release.

OBEY is very fun and unique multiplayer PvP game about oppression, obedience, subversion, deception, bribery, and all the other fun things you can never have in real life! ;-) It's highly based on communication, and the social interaction makes every round a unique experience. I strongly (!) recommend using a headset/mic to get the full experience.

Each player in the game controls a cute llittle nameless bunny, and to win the round you must earn money faster than your competitors.
Per default, the earning rate is the same for everyone, except the one bunny controlling the giant, armed-to-the-teeth robot gorilla in the middle of the map, who earns like 10 times!

So will you instantly go for the robot and try to rule them all? To secure your reign, you will have to spend the bigger part of your earnings to buy weapons and resources and then bribe your competitors into feeding those items into your feedbox, and set up defences.

Be a merciless and punishing ruler, killing everyone who disobeys the slightest, and you risk a revolution...
Be a mild and generous sovereign, and you will be used and manipulated into ultimately losing money faster than your clever subordinates earn, only to be pushed from the throne in a second of inattention by simply walking through the robot's front door.

And then there's of course always the subversive ones, constantly trying to manipulate, sneaking around, outright lying or stealing your money by hiding your purchases or dropping dead bunnies in your feedbox....

I had a lot of fun in the few matches I had so far, and I can highly recommend the game to everyone who wants to experience something different"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fairly unique multiplayer game of being a Bunny and trying to take control of a giant gun and earn power and money using a combination of honesty, deception, obedience, mutiny, servitude, manipulation, lying, cheating, stealing and all the other C.V. ruining human traits. It's the first Steam release from an American developer with a brief history in game art and development, and comes with a unique mix of gameplay elements which sometimes make for really interesting player interactions and psychological situations.

After playing for just a couple of days I found myself beginning to analyse people mid-conversation in my day to day life, wondering if they were lying to me about trivial things for monetary gain, half-expecting them to hide in a piece of furniture and rush at me when I wasn't watching. It's a game which undoubtedly gets in your head when you play too much.

Full disclosure: I have no affiliation with the developer, but did recieve a key.

Consisting of a medium sized map with up to 10 Bunny players, the sole objective in OBEY is to amass as much money as possible, but the methods for accomplishing this vary based on the current player:power scenario and can shift in an instant. One central gun/watchtower called the Robosaru exists per map, a Power Plant which generates money for the player inside the Robosaru, and a Feed Box where Bunnys can deposit items to generate money for the Overlord, and usually make money for themselves in the process.

Whoever commands the Robosaru has a distinct advantage in the form of 10x passive income, and of course deadly control, but it comes at the cost of everyone trying to steal that control either through direct attacks, or by lying, manipulating and sabotaging the Overlord or any combination of their fellow Bunnys in persuit of their own paycheck. Because it becomes increasingly difficult to watch more than a Bunny or two, the Overlord must work together to keep himself safe, similarly Bunnys want to stay alive and profit more, which means that the dynamics constantly change based on how many players are in the game, how much money they have, what they're assumed attitude towards each other is, and what they actually accomplish.

Highlights
At a higher level OBEY about out thinking your fellow players. In the early stages I routinely found myself asking for more money for performing actions, and being a sort of salesman for myself. When I learned that I could cheat my fellow Bunnys by lying about their actions, a new avenue of options opened up. This lack of strict limitation and the utility of psychological warfare via spoken commands and text brings the gameplay to a higher level than simply running around trying to earn money and directly sabotage the current winner, and it's where the game shines.

The visual style is also very worth pointing out. Maps tend to be very simple, and I personally love the low polygon approach to the assets. The animations and movement are also well correlated with the visuals, and having a group of Bunnys all turn their heads to stare at me in the hull of a gloomy-lit ambient Dropship ended up being far more creepy than it rightfully should've been.

Mistakes and Annoyances
Being in Early-Access, technical issues are less of an issue and though I had a few small technical problems every single one of them was mentioned on the development panel as currently being worked on. There are still technical issues worth bringing attention to though, like lag and server drops which are common. The server console is fairly flat and bland and utilizes an IRC channel which comes with pros and cons, and the server client for hosting your own games is completely unmentioned in game, and I only found it through a mention on the website.
There's also a real lack of options for play just now. There are a handful of dedicated servers with various configurations, and each round has a small pool of maps to select from, but there's currently only a couple of US server and maybe a handful in the EU, so if your ping isn't particularly good you're probably going to be limited to a server or two at best, and if you're inexperienced or looking for different gameplay types, you're going to be waiting for far too long to connect to a good server.

Which brings up the biggest problem with this title: the lack of players. It's great fun when there are enough people around, and genuinely addictive and intense gameplay takes place, especially with people you know, but currently the community is only really palpable during a very specific set of hours and if you know more than a handful of players then you're unlikely to play with people you haven't mostly already seen. This wouldn't be a problem in most games, but here if you know what to expect from a player or they remember what you did the last few games, there's probably a disadvantage for one of you and a bias towards the same gameplay unfolding.

I expect this game to grow over time, and it's a game more than any other I've found that will become better with a larger community in place, so it's a real problem when there's no effort to grow the player base other than perhaps a Steam group and the developer forums. While the current community is definitely great fun to play with, and well in tune with the spirit of the game, it's still both drastically dependent upon, and lacking in players.

Recommendations
You can pick up OBEY just now for £10.99/14.99€/$14.99 or your regional equivalent, and the 4-Pack option saves you a chunky 40% if you have a couple of friends. As with all multiplayer games, your value for money is subjective based on how much you're likely to play, but when compared to other popular multiplayer titles on Steam, this is priced on the higher end, though it doesn't have in-game purchases or DLC to worry about.

While finding people to play with can be an issue, if you expect the player base to grow then this is a fair buy, and good value for money if you go for the 4-Pack option. If you need a good multiplayer scene then you might want to wait til after release, for a sale, or until the player levels reach a better level.

I received this game for free from the developer for the purposes of review

I don't think I can categorize this game into a genre, I haven't played many like it
I guess it may resemble arena games a little; the game requires a mix of social skills, strategy and decision making, although a bit of luck won't hurt.

In this game, you're mostly a small rodent - except when you aren't. Your purpose in the scary little world you're in is to follow orders - except when you'd rather not. Sounds a little confusing I suppose. But basically you could be an obedient little worker bee and keep big brother happy, or you could pretty much do anything you want as long as you don't get caught. Talking to the other players in this game is a big part of the experience, and the push to talk and push to mute options built into the game work very nicely. The atmosphere created by the dark environment, the flood lights, and the rodents fragility is Orwellian, I found myself thinking about old school Sci-Fi books. The Robot is a lot like big brother, something in the game also kept making me think of Asimov, though I'm not sure what. On the whole the game is very good at pulling you in, just alt tabbing from it feels like you're going to another world.

That said, it's not easy figuring out what you want to do in the game, and if you ignore the tutorial like I did (you really shouldn't), you'll just find yourself working like an obedient little sheep, and you'll miss out on all the hidden little things you can in the game. (Tip: try crashing the carrier, the little marshmallow in a campfire explosions are worth it)
Techinically the game has a goal and a win condition, but it's not enforced, and I like that.

Pros: Stable on PC and Mac
Simple concept, very easy to get started in, but has a lot of fun little secrets to discover

Cons: The tutorial failed to grab my attention.
This is a social game, and if you're the kind of person who would rather play GMod, than solo grind a single player game, then you'll enjoy OBEY.

7/10 a great game if you want to mess around with your friends.

Few things you need to know before you get into this game:
Multiplayer only.
You do want to play it with friends.
Headset/microphone is highly recommended.This game is nothing like I’ve ever played before. You either play as a harmless bunny or a killer robot.

As a robot you command a bunch of bunnies (vocally or via text/on-screen commands). Bunnies have to bring you (robot) ammo, fuel, batteries, etc and do tasks like building defenses around you. You reward them by paying salary.

As a bunny you must obey your robot overlord… or not. Robot has a “money generator” and you can sabotage robot’s income by turning generator off. There are other ways to ruin robot’s day. Most importantly, if you are sneaky enough, you can get inside the robot yourself and become the new overlord :) If you don’t obey and act fishy robot will send you to sweet bunny heaven in an instant.

It is a roleplaying game in sense that everyone has to play a role (there is no inventory, experience or anything like that). Quality of gameplay highly depends on the ability of players to be able to embrace their roles. Headset certainly makes communication more fun.

I applaud the developer for trying something unique rather than using Unity engine to make another minecraft clone and I do hope this game becomes successful enough for the servers to get populated. At this moment community is very small and there are barely any people playing.

OBEY is a really unique multiplayer game that's quite difficult to describe really. In each match you start off by playing a Bunny and in the arena there is a large looming tower that can be controlled by one player. You have a choice as to how you choose to play. The player who controls the tower issues commands to the other players and then they can choose whether or not you want to obey (hence the name!) those commands or not. You might want to obey the commands from the tower and play the game that way, or you might try to rebel and take over the tower!

The game play is very strategic, especially if you manage to get control of the tower. There are a ton of items in the game arena that can be used in different ways and add a huge amount of depth to the game. You'll certainly need to play through the tutorial but this isn't enough really. This is still in Early Access so hopefully the tutorial will be expanded in the future but in the meantime I'd recommend watching some Youtube videos to get a better idea of how it works.

You can play on a LAN using a private server or you can join an online one. When I tested it there were only a handful of empty servers online so hopefully more people will pick this up and the servers will become more populated.

Being the master can be a double-edged sword, because while you do make a ton of money, the bunnies under your heel have many ways to make you lose all of it very quickly.  The best part about this game is that it's very possible to NEVER be in the robot and still win.

One game I was playing, one player was in the robot for the majority of the game.  He had 8,000 points and climbing (you need 10,000 to win) while everybody else was at about 3,000 or less.  I spent some of my points to buy laser walls, an item that sets up a deadly trap that kills any bunny that touches it.  When my compatriots and I were delivered back to the game via dropship after being killed, two of my rivals foolishly decided to make a break for the robot.  While the robot was distracted with annihilating them, I ran into an area the robot couldn't see and set up my trap.

Now, the interesting part in this game is that a dead bunny's corpse significantly lower's the robot's score when delivered to the robot's delivery area.  The robot can get resources (missiles, flamethrower fuel) and points if bunnies deliver items there, but delivering a dead bunny lowers their score quite significantly.  I committed suicide on the trap I had set up outside of the robot's vision about half a dozen times, then delivered my bunny's charred remains over and over.  The guy that was moments away from winning and had been in the robot the entire game now had negative points and couldn't afford to bribe other players into doing his bidding.  Every single bunny in the game (except me) then spent their points to overload the dropship and crash it, which causes dead bunnies to spawn at random points on the map instead of being delivered to a fixed area (at least until the ship is replaced, which is expensive).  Now there was an uprising and the robot changed hands quite a few times.

Nobody found out about my trap and corpse-making machine.  Every single time someone new got in the robot, I destroyed their score and rose through the ranks until I was in the lead.  I never obeyed the robot but I never tried to take over either.  I ended up winning that particular match because I kept committing suicide over and over, then pulling off heists and stealthily avoiding the robot's gaze.

No other game I've ever played offers an experience like that.  This game is phenomenal, and the developer regularly logs in to teach new players about the game (he's also an evil dictator when he's in the robot, don't listen to him).  I highly recommend anybody that's interested in a more intellectual and socially interesting game to give it a try.

==== Should You Buy This Game? ====OBEY is a very fun cooperative (or should I say uncooperative) multiplayer game. I originally had mixed feelings about this game due to a relatively poor tutorial, but once I managed to understand how OBEY is truly played, it became a blast. The two-faced style of gameplay can lead to some hilariously memorable moments. A couple words of advice before purchasing this game. The player base is still relatively small, and that is something that can only be remedied with you and your friends’ help. The purchasing format heavily discounts a 4-pack purchase. If you decide to go in on OBEY, I would recommend getting some friends in to help with a 4-pack purchase.

==== First Impressions ====----11/25/2015----
There are two positions you may take part of when starting the game. You may play as a cute little bunny, scheming, plotting and looking for ways to overthrow the evil overseer controlling the robot of doom while maintaining a very obedient front in order to survive. Alternatively, you may play as the evil overseer controlling the robot of doom ensuring that those lying little devious monsters do your bidding. The main actions that the robot can take include killing the bunnies, deactivating hidden mines to help the bunnies stay alive, change pay scales in order to incentivize the bunnies to give you certain supplies (needed for ammo/security) etc. The main actions that the bunnies can perform include purchasing and feeding supplies to the robot, setting up security for the robot, warning the robot of bunnies making a break for the robot control room, or make a break for the robot control room.

Coordinating is much easier using a microphone. Although there are forms of communication without it, warning the robot of bunny locations can be difficult.

==== Current State of the Game ====There were no noticeable bugs found in my short play through, however there are couple important suggestions I feel if implemented will help improve the gameplay.

Suggestions: Include basic strategies in the tutorial/provide a better understanding of the actions you can perform as a bunny/robot. It took a few gameplay videos to get the grasp of how to play
Improve communication options for those without a microphone
Make a cute little introduction cut scene/animation explaining the bunnies’ predicament

Obey is a multiplayer strategy game in which the player that reaches a certain amount of money (usually 10000) wins. To do that you can either obey the overlord and get rewarded for well-behaving (though that depends on how generous the current overlord is) while you slowly earn money, or overthrow the overlord, become the new ruler, earn money faster and turn the rest of the players into your lackeys.

- Use a microphone. This game requires a lot of social interaction and, while you can use a keyboard to send messages, it's way easier and more comfortable to just talk. Also you can't shoot down rebels while typing =P

In short, if you like strategy games based on social interaction then this game is perfect for you.

OBEY is an interesting take on the asymmetrical multiplayer game.  The overlord is the man behind the giant gorilla turret and can see almost your every move.  The other players are bunnies who can assist the overlord or stage a coup and try and become the gunner themselves.

Currently, the game is quite fun and look forward to the additional content that is planned for OBEY.  The art style is fitting, the controls worked as expected, and the in-game chat had no issues.

The few improvements I would like to see are a better HUD for the overlord since there are so many abilities at your disposal and a slightly more in depth tutorial (the first game I played I really didn't understand the flow of the game).

TL:DR  - Fun asymmetrical multiplayer only game with a great premise and a little light on content.  Recommended.

Early Access Review

Obey is a very unique concept, unlike anything I've seen on (or off) Steam before.

You are in charge of a giant robot, dictator of bunnies across the land...

OR

You are a bunny, with dreams of becoming the giant robot which you Obey.

This is not a single player experience. Visuals are basic but colourful and fitting for the game. The controls are easy to pick up.

Tutorial level gives a lot of information without any other players, and it can therefore be difficult to imagine a game in practice. The inclusion of some AI for tutorial purposes may have been helpful. The tutorial did cover most of the detail of the game though.

Gameplay is fun, however at the EA stage it is difficult to find other players on mostly empty servers.

The community seems friendly, as to the developers. With any luck this game will spend a long time in Early Access to allow the fine points of the game to be polished to perfection.

I played Crypt of the Necrodancer through the early access stage and the input from the community and openness from the developers was vital in creating what became an incredibly fun and unique experience - one which I have since happily put hundreds of hours into. I hope Obey continues in a similar vain.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Headphone users be warned: when launching the game for the first time, the music in the main menu will be deafening. I would have liked to see an audio control when launching the game, as there already is one for the video settings.

OBEY is a multi-player only game. While the servers are low-populated, the game does include bots. Something I think any MP-only game should have. In this game, every player controls a bunny. You have won when you have earned the most money out of all the players. You earn money automatically, but you can speed things up considerably by collecting clutter. Clutter give you money upon delivery at delivery points. You can only carry 2 items at a time if you're wearing a collar, or 3 times at a time if you're not wearing a collar.

Then there's a giant robot on the map that can be controlled by one player. In order to take control of this robot, 'all' you have to do is walk to the door and whoever was in control of the robot (if any) will get thrown out. I put all between apostrophes because while it sounds easy, when you're playing against more experienced opponents it proves to be a lot more difficult than initially thought. That's because the person controlling the robot can kill any bunny on the map. The robot player also makes 10x the amount of money that other players make. The robot player can threaten bunnies and give them commands. Or try to keep the bunnies befriended, by rewarding them for tasks by giving them more money.

So you would think that the most logical strategy would be to sprint for the robot, take control, and kill everyone until the end of the game, right? Wrong. This is where the community aspect of it kicks in. This game is all about psychology. If you are killing everyone, why would anyone obey you? Instead, you'll see players group up and riot against you. The robot player can buy bunnies a collar, making them more visible. But bunnies can take these off and go 'rogue'. When rogue, they are still visible but it becomes a lot more difficult. Due to the terrain it is impossible for the robot player to see every inch of the map, making it possible for bunnies to get closer to the door and take over control.

This is also why you would create pacts if you're the robot player. By having loyalists telling you if they spot a rogue, it becomes easier to defend your control of the robot. But then again, someone could lie about a rogue's position distracting you from their real position. Besides that, you also have to rely on other bunnies: any clutter turned in, gets delivered to the robot player. If you notice there's a bunny at your door when they're already too close for your bullets to hit them, you can still use the flame-thrower to kill them. But in order to use the flame-thrower, you need fuel. You can buy this yourself, but you need money to win so it's preferable if a player deposits it instead. Also, when a bunny deposits a corpse, left behind when a bunny gets burned, that will cause the robot player to lose some of their money instantly.

There are a lot more items in the game that I didn't cover in this review, because it would have been too long. There are topics in the discussions section that cover all of those. What I can say about them briefly, is that the items are very diverse and well-thought about. There are mines to trick other bunnies, Lights to light up areas for the robot player, rockets as additional ammunition for the robot player and more.

So you can choose to be a cruel dictator, and grind it out if you're playing against not so skilled opponents. Or be a kind ruler, and get betrayed by a bunny eventually. Either way people, will be out to get you in order to win the game themselves. Like I said before, this game is all about psychology. It involves a lot of trickery and bargaining.

The graphics look simple, but they are done really well. It feeds the cuteness of the bunnies and their bunny world. The animations are also very nice. The sound effects, I thought, fit the game perfectly. All in all I think this is a really fun game, at its best when played with a group of friends. But as a beginner, even playing against bots were fun and challenging.

OBEY is a game that runs absolutely terrible on my turd of a PC. Nor does it run on my 2010 Macbook (Non-Pro) with only 2 GB of RAM.

With that being said, here is my semi in depth review.

Obey is a First Person multiplayer game that sets itself apart from most by focusing on team based play. It can be played online, or with bots, though the bots tend to be pretty easy. It can seem very chaotic and difficult to understand at first, although once one masters the gameplay it gets less confusing. The game's tutorial tries to teach you how to play a little, showing you what different items do and how the game works. Gameplay is basically like a very complicated King Of The Hill, in which players feed items into a massive robot controlled by one player in order to try to earn money so then the player controlling the robot can give back more items and money to the players. In terms that a sane person will understand, to win you basically need to make the most money.

Overall, the game is worth buying for people that are looking for an interesting multiplayer experience that strives to be different from your average online game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you were lucky to play Obey with human players not bots you will notice how smart the gameplay concept is. All the players are trying to get into a robot to take control of everything on the map and give orders to other players to do what you want them to do. It's not about shooting others, it's about making them Obey your orders. This concept is so cool but in my own opinion it lacks a lot. The futuristic theme of the game and the bunnies the players take control of doesn't match the idea and the goal of the game. What if instead of bunnies there was a weak miserable dobby-like creatures. What if instead of the peaceful backyard garden the current map looks like there was a desert wasteland, a poisonous swamp or even a dark and scary place that makes the player feel like he is being enslaved. To sum it up: there is nothing good about this game other than the concept and the nice dev who is willing to play with you just to show you how the game should be played, everything else is a mess.
